author: Okmanl
body:
The best strategy when it comes to investing is one that limits emotions as much as possible. Buying and holding is that strategy. Buying and looking at your portfolio all the time to determine when to sell, puts you at greater risk for emotions to get involved. Then you end up being one of those people selling PLTR for only 10% gains. Or MSFT/TSLA/LMND right before it they took off after trading sideways for a while. 

 The best performing portfolios tend to belong to those who have died or those who’ve forgotten they even had a portfolio. Not those who actively trade. 


Lastly you don’t know whether or not a company will suddenly do a complete 180 like AMD when Lisa Su took over or MSFT when Satya took over. Which is why I advocate just holding onto your assets.

author: ElmerFUDz
body:
When Bill Gates retired from Microsoft a few years back, Jimmy kimmel was apparently called upon to participate in a final-day roast of the billionaire software tycoon. Unfortunately, Kimmel says the joke-fest didn’t go so well.

 Kimmel explained that although he was led to believe that Gates was on board with the roast, he didn’t seem to find Kimmel’s routine funny in the slightest.

“It was a disaster. I insisted that he be onstage with me if I was going to do this, because the key to a roast is the people in the audience see the roastee laughing. Well, unfortunately, the roastee was not laughing. Not even a little bit.”

One of Kimmel’s jokes was that the only reason why Bill Gates didn’t get a perfect score on the SAT was because he missed the one that asks what a vagina looks like.


Kimmel went on to say that the only person in the room who laughed at his jokes was Tesla CEO Elon Musk. “He was laughing like a maniac,” the late-night host recalled. “Which in a way made it worse.”

By the end of the night, Kimmel said that Gates was referring to him simply as “the comedian.”

“He was like, ‘We couldn’t get Jay Leno for this?'"

author: LaPulgaAtomica87
body:
You're absolutely right---actually you made one minor mistake you're comparing the June 18 QQQJ call to the June 30 QQQ call. The price of the June 18 QQQ call is ~ $5.70 which buttresses your point even more. 

And you can see this from their IV: QQQJ has an IV of 28% while QQQ has an IV of 21%. So yes, all things being equal, QQQ is cheaper than QQQJ.

All that said, I am still balls deep in QQQJ calls because I believe over the next year, it will outperform QQQ for the reason OP stated: it has many more beaten down companies than QQQ. The big boys in QQQ have all recovered for the most part. Another crucial point is that QQQJ has more non-tech companies so if there is a rotation out of tech, it will suffer less than QQQ.

I'm very bullish about this etf. I saw a WSJ article where someone did a historic backtest from 2016 or 2017 and QQQJ outperformed QQQ even with the insane run of the big boys MSFT, AAPL, NVDA & ADBE during that period.

author: Meymo
body:
It reminds me of this thought: *When does the breadth of contemporary evidence supersede the depth of historical data?*

Generally, I agree with your overall sentiment, but not for the reasons you cite here. I think there's a couple of things being conflated in the messaging. First, a 3-fund portfolio isn't going to get you some kind of multi-digit percentage return most of the time. You invest in a 3-fund portfolio if you're trying to preserve your money. Comparing a 3-fund portfolio to (insert growth fund here) isn't quite a fair comparison because the goals are different.

Additionally, I will point out that thematic investing isn't new. ARK and others have been following themes to great success, and as long as the theme remains hot (technology, clean energy, genomics, medical devices, etc.) the funds will continue to do well. [IHI](https://www.portfoliovisualizer.com/backtest-portfolio?s=y&timePeriod=4&startYear=1985&firstMonth=1&endYear=2020&lastMonth=12&calendarAligned=true&includeYTD=false&initialAmount=10000&annualOperation=0&annualAdjustment=0&inflationAdjusted=true&annualPercentage=0.0&frequency=4&rebalanceType=1&absoluteDeviation=5.0&relativeDeviation=25.0&showYield=false&reinvestDividends=true&benchmark=VFINX&portfolioNames=false&portfolioName1=Portfolio+1&portfolioName2=Portfolio+2&portfolioName3=Portfolio+3&symbol1=IHI&allocation1_1=100), for example, has done a compounding return of of 15% per year since inception (2007), blowing away the SPY in all metrics (less drawdowns, higher return, lower volatility, etc.).

Traditional thinking states that you can't beat the market over time, so why even bother trying. People who believe this accept it as fact, when there are so many other factors involved (e.g. was the person who picked stocks buying the same stocks every time they got paid?).  I expect this notion to be challenged over the next decade, and quite frankly, I hope the thinking dies out. There are plenty of funds and folks buying baskets of stocks (e.g. 10-20 stocks) especially now with fractional shares weighted for specific targets and are continuing to ascend to new highs.

As much as people want to speak poorly of strategies that differ from their index investing, rarely have I ever seen someone address the elephant in the room which is, "By not investing in the index, you were able to beat the index." I've had many debates here about this because there is a camp of diehards who refuse to look at any kind of alternative data. If I say [here's an example of a basket of 3 stocks that has beat the SPY for the past 26+ years](https://www.portfoliovisualizer.com/backtest-portfolio?s=y&timePeriod=4&startYear=1985&firstMonth=1&endYear=2020&lastMonth=12&calendarAligned=true&includeYTD=false&initialAmount=100000&annualOperation=0&annualAdjustment=0&inflationAdjusted=true&annualPercentage=0.0&frequency=4&rebalanceType=1&absoluteDeviation=5.0&relativeDeviation=25.0&showYield=false&reinvestDividends=true&benchmark=VFINX&portfolioNames=false&portfolioName1=Portfolio+1&portfolioName2=Portfolio+2&portfolioName3=Portfolio+3&symbol1=MSFT&allocation1_1=33&symbol2=WM&allocation2_1=33&symbol3=INTU&allocation3_1=34), is that enough evidence to show that consistently beating the market is at least *possible?? (put your pitchforks down, I did not say guaranteed).* I've been talking about this for the entire lifecycle of this reddit account, so it's nothing new.

If you're a person who is looking for outsized returns, you'll need to go outside the index. Momentum is one strategy that has consistently worked to accomplish this.

Good luck

author: FartSpeller
body:
I’m gonna make this real simple for you.  Forget about the names of the Greeks for a min, (since you don’t know what they mean anyway 😉). 

Every option contract premium (how much it costs to buy said contract) is the total of its intrinsic value and extrinsic value. 

Intrinsic value is how far in the money the contract is.  So, if MSFT is $215, and you have a $210 strike call, there is $5 (per share) of intrinsic value there.  That means you’re holding a contract that lets you buy shares $5 cheaper than on the open market.  Now, people who sell options are smarter than you, so they aren’t going to let you just have that $5/share for free so the contract is gonna cost you that $5 and then some. 

The “and then some” is the extrinsic value.  This is your gambling fee.  And extrinsic value disappears.  100% of extrinsic value is gone at expiration, every time, every contract, no exception. So if the MSFT contract we were talking about above was going for $6.00, that means there’s $5 of intrinsic value and $1 of extrinsic value. 

Now, to bring this all together for you smooth brain idiots to understand.  Only extrinsic value is impacted by theta and Vega.  I know, right. Weird huh.  

So with the MSFT contract above, $1 out of the $6 it cost you is subjected to IV crush or theta. So 16% of the value of your contract is impacted by Vega (IV)or theta (time).  The further you are in the money, the more intrinsic value you have, and less extrinsic.  Therefore, less of your contract would be subjected to the bleed of Vega or theta. 

When you buy an OTM option, it is 100% extrinsic value.  So, 100% of the contract is subject to theta and Vega bleed.

author: Killtrend
body:
TL;DR at the bottom. You are the reason I’m still subbed to Pennystocks after moving over to more serious companies. (No offense).. a reminder of really bad ideas stemming from pump and dumps. I got sucked into ATNM. Twice.  

Honestly, and harshly, It’s better you lose $2500 than 5,000. You just paid your market tuition of $2500. Everyone does. I paid $1200 to a shitty Microsoft weekly option contract I shouldn’t have bought as my first option trade. 3 months later I made that back plus 3500 off 1-2k option investments (usually much less) at a time. (After that 1200 loss I also doubled down on studying, paper trading, and YouTube lessons. Dozens and dozens of hours before I made another trade). Take it on the chin and use that 2500 tax loss to offset your taxes. I’ve taken losses of $700, 1200, and two separate 200 losses since sept 1st (there’s more but those are the biggest.) If your strategy is good you’ll make it back. 

Btw you’re $5,000 investment in that company is 6% of their revenue for Q3. So. There’s that. 

TL;DR - Take the loss, claim it on your taxes. Do not buy back in or you’ll trigger a wash sale. 

-edit- Doing some quick research on them... and wow. They apparently used to be “On The Move Systems Corp” and it does not look good. Take your loss and move on my friend.

author: Teh-alt-write
body:
It allowed fractional shares before pretty much everyone else. You build a Pie (like a pie chart) with the percentages of the stocks you want. 

You could do for example: 25% VOO, 10% TQQQ, 3% TSLA, 15% PLTR, 20% GME, 5% MSFT, 22% ARKF. 

You can also have a pie within a pie. For example take 25% and make it whatever you want. The pie can have a theme, or not. 

They also have expert pies with stocks and bonds or target dates for retirement. Btw, you can have a retirement account there and set it as Roth, Traditional, etc.

author: ElmerFUDz
body:
When Bill Gates retired from Microsoft a few years back, Jimmy kimmel was apparently called upon to participate in a final-day roast of the billionaire software tycoon. Unfortunately, Kimmel says the joke-fest didn’t go so well.

 Kimmel explained that although he was led to believe that Gates was on board with the roast, he didn’t seem to find Kimmel’s routine funny in the slightest.

“It was a disaster. I insisted that he be onstage with me if I was going to do this, because the key to a roast is the people in the audience see the roastee laughing. Well, unfortunately, the roastee was not laughing. Not even a little bit.”


Kimmel went on to say that the only person in the room who laughed at his jokes was Tesla CEO Elon Musk. “He was laughing like a maniac,” the late-night host recalled. “Which in a way made it worse.”

By the end of the night, Kimmel said that Gates was referring to him simply as “the comedian.”

“He was like, ‘We couldn’t get Jay Leno for this?'"

author: BigLeJaffe
body:
>2 trillion evaluation

2 trillion is only 4x from now. That means, to quadruple your money at this valuation (not astronomical gains by any means), Tesla would have to outpace Amazon, Microsoft, Google and Apple to become the most valuable company in the world. Looking at current profit and revenue doesn't matter because all stocks are priced on expectation, but the valuation does matter because it's an indicator of just how large a company's projected future value will be. I personally find the idea that this company will make more money than Apple one day to be ludicrous.

author: dotobird
body:
I don't understand this Steam fantasy. Why wouldn't you just buy games directly from Microsoft or Sony? What is being like Steam supposed to accomplish? 

I think the future of Gamestop is still physical games. People will still buy physical games over digital games (as long as the option is there) because it gives them the ability to resell. Gamestop will **NEVER** go back to its previous revenue high's without its resale business.

author: mtcoope
body:
Its funny I'm a software developer and I think machine learning might be one the biggest buzz/hype words that exist at the moment. Dont get me wrong i think it has a future but every company I've worked at that experimented with it all had 1 common problem. Getting enough clean data to train a model. I guess my thing is its going to come but I dont think we are close to it taking over. 

Cloud services are where the money is now and I think will continue to grow rapidly. Its boring but Microsoft and Amazon.

author: veritasinvestments
body: Great question bruh. Not sure when exactly this buyout will be finalized. Went through some more stuff and it seems like their fiscal year ends in March, which means management may actually end up fully selling in March, but at the same time, DXC (the company that prsp was split from) just got a BO offer from this French company. It’s really interesting how both companies are being bought out at the same time. 30c Jans are still above the price I recommended them at (I said buy at 0.1, now at 0.3) so if you’re up, take some profits perhaps.

author: Forsaken-Pangolin-57
body: So I’m pretty out of my depth here. It’s a work project, but I’m essentially first trying to determine whether they were over or undersubscribed. Oversubscribed meaning that more ParentCo shares are tendered than new company shares are offered than exchange is done on a pro-rata basis. Usually, some sort of 8K or company press release state that the offer is oversubscribed. There’s a handful I’m looking at that don’t explicitly state it one way or the other, and I’m just trying to determine what happened in these deals (GE and Wabec, HPE and Micro Focus, HPE and DXC, Starwood and ILG, Nabors and C&J Energy Services, Tyco and Pentair). Doing this to look at employee equity when deals are undersubscribed.
